request_pathways.name: Mail to HIM Department (Moses H. Cone Memorial Hospital, 1200 N Elm Street, Greensboro, NC 27401)

access_pathway.primary_pathway_description: Patient downloads a generic HIPAA authorization PDF from the Medical Records page, checks 'Patient Request' as purpose, fills the form by hand, and submits via fax or mail to the HIM department.

red_flags: No submission instructions on the form — no address, fax number, or email for where to send the completed authorization

Bundled sensitive-category consent with no opt-out — signing authorizes release of mental health, substance abuse, HIV/AIDS, genetic, and reproductive health records regardless of what is actually requested
CHMG form (form-4) embeds a liability waiver into the authorization, requiring patients to release Cone Health from legal responsibility as a condition of authorizing disclosure
Two separate ROI forms for hospital vs. medical group with no guidance on which to use
bright_spots: Spanish-language version of the authorization form available and linked from the Medical Records page
Email delivery option offered with transparent security disclaimer
Granular record-type selection with 18+ checkboxes including a dedicated behavioral health subsection

findability.rationale: Level 4: The primary form is directly linked from a logically-named Medical Records page reachable through standard patient navigation, though the CHMG form is only discoverable via web search and bot protection adds friction.

technical_accessibility.rationale: Level 2: The primary form has zero fillable fields requiring a fully paper workflow (print, handwrite); no submission fax number or address is provided on the form itself, though fax submission is presumably available through the HIM department.

content_design.rationale: Level 3: The form has a logical numbered structure and reasonable organization, but uses clinical terminology patients won't understand, dense legal language in the rights section, and lacks submission instructions.

patient_centeredness.rationale: Level 3: A patient can request their own records by checking 'Patient Request' on the generic authorization form, but the form was designed for third-party disclosures and requires patients to navigate irrelevant fields and figure out which of two forms applies to them.

compliance.rationale: Level 3: The form bundles consent for all sensitive information categories with no opt-out, provides vague fee disclosure without referencing HIPAA limits, and the CHMG form includes a non-standard liability waiver — though the hospital form correctly addresses treatment conditioning and 42 CFR Part 2.

overall.summary: Cone Health provides a functional but patient-unfriendly records request process centered on a non-fillable generic HIPAA authorization form with no dedicated patient access pathway, no submission instructions, and bundled sensitive-category consent.
